intro: Lappula californica, commonly known as California lappula, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae and is characterized by its small, yellowish flowers and succulent leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in coastal areas. Its flowering period occurs in late spring to early summer, and it produces small, round seeds that are dispersed by wind. Lappula californica is adapted to arid environments and is considered a hardy, drought-tolerant species.
